body: In the meantime, I wil try a release.
Same on the latest release.

This fails because `memorySize`, needed by the usage reporting function, is not implemented for OpenBSD. The simples fix for you is to change `// +build freebsd` to `// +build freebsd,openbsd` in `cmd/syncthing/memsize_unimpl.go` - it's not implemented for FreeBSD either. Try that and let me know how it works out?
If it works otherwise, I could add OpenBSD to the build targets and add binaries for it, I guess.

Using the following diff:

```
diff --git a/cmd/syncthing/memsize_unimpl.go b/cmd/syncthing/memsize_unimpl.go
index c226efa..a6ba87a 100644
--- a/cmd/syncthing/memsize_unimpl.go
+++ b/cmd/syncthing/memsize_unimpl.go
@@ -13,7 +13,7 @@
 // You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License along
 // with this program. If not, see <http://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.

-// +build freebsd
+// +build freebsd,openbsd

 package main
```

I still get:

```
...
github.com/vitrun/qart/qr
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/files
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/stats
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stindex
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/model
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/syncthing
# github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/syncthing
cmd/syncthing/usage_report.go:80: undefined: memorySize
exit status 2
exit status 1
```

I get the impression it is still not building `memsize_unimpl.go`.

Re, adding to the build. Let's talk about it. Is there an IRC channel you guys hang on?
I screwed up the syntax, it should be a space instead of a comma. Fixed, now with build: http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing/

Thanks, that seems to work. If I had known the first thing about go, I would have been able to fix that myself. Really must learn.

Regarding distributing binaries. OpenBSD binaries have a very limited shelf life. As soon as a base library bumps (libc and libpthread in this case), it will not run. Libraries are bumped frequently. You could distribute a binary for each release, but many OpenBSD users run rolling snapshots.

I thought perhaps I had heard that go libraries were statically linked, but I guess not:

```
$ ldd ./bin/syncthing 
./bin/syncthing:
        Start            End              Type Open Ref GrpRef Name
        0000000000400000 0000000000d50000 exe  1    0   0      ./bin/syncthing
        0000000281c65000 0000000282077000 rlib 0    2   0      /usr/lib/libpthread.so.18.1
        000000021b14b000 000000021b635000 rlib 0    1   0      /usr/lib/libc.so.77.2
        00000002e6c00000 00000002e6c00000 rtld 0    1   0      /usr/libexec/ld.so
```

Anyway, thanks for your help. I'm going to have a play with this today :)

It depends on how you build. The binary from my build server ought to be statically linked, since it's cross compiled (and thus have a longer shelf life?). When you compile natively, you get a dynamic binary by default.
I see.
Anyway, I'll provide the binary from now on since the extra effort is ~0. :) If it's works that's cool, otherwise I guess people are used to compiling on their own.

I haven't actually checked to see it is all functioning yet, but I will try later and let you know.

I was at Aral's talk yesterday. I like where indi.ie is heading. Thanks for your efforts.

great, thanks! :four_leaf_clover: OpenBSD folks generally fear precompiled binaries for good reasons, at least as long as they are not [packaged](http://www.openbsd.org/faq/faq15.html) in the OpenBSD-proper way. could try to hack a [port](http://www.openbsd.org/faq/ports/ports.html) and add it to [openbsd-wip](https://github.com/jasperla/openbsd-wip) ports for testing if desired:grey_question:
@gretel That's next on my list. Just going to have a play and check it all works first.
@vext01 so i'd test happily if you commit to openbsd-wip. regards
I'll let you know once I am at that point. This would be the first port using go by the looks of it, so we might have to figure a few bits out. For example there is no go.port.mk yet.
@vext01 glad you give it a go! :smile: yep, and having that out of openbsd-wip will take lots of testing.

Well, here is a rough port:
https://github.com/jasperla/openbsd-wip/tree/master/net/pulse

However, this isn't going to make it in it's current state. The build system appears to download moving target dependencies. We can't have that.

To make this work we would need to build ports for each dependency and make sure that go's build system can never download anything. Any idea how I can do the latter?

These problems are similar to the ones we have with node.js.

oh been missing that because have been searching for `syncthing` not `pulse`. unfortunately i just get _go_-ing because of pulse. i tend to get support on [freenode irc](https://webchat.freenode.net/?channels=openbsd), takes a while sometimes but interesting questions get answered most of the time.
Well, it's more a go problem than an openbsd problem. I'm wondering if I could disable networking in the go build system via systrace.

[sure](http://cr.yp.to/unix/disablenetwork.html) but guess a hack like this won't be accepted neither. go core seems to [like openbsd](https://code.google.com/p/go/issues/detail?id=8642&q=openbsd&colspec=ID%20Status%20Stars%20Release%20Owner%20Repo%20Summary) so maybe getting in touch with them might help.

The syncthing build system shouldn't download anything at all under normal circumstances.

To run test coverage etc, extra tools are needed.
I see. You are right, but there are a load of external sources in `Godeps`. Did you manually download those into the source tree?
@calmh, please enlighten us :zap:
